newsitem.title: USA: Tobacco firms to appeal Mass. disclosure ruling.
newsitem.headline: Tobacco firms to appeal Mass. disclosure ruling.

text.p: Four tobacco companies said on Friday they will appeal a federal judge's ruling that upheld a Massachusetts law requiring them to disclose the ingredients in their brands.

"We will seek leave to appeal immediately," said David Remes, a Washington-based lawyer acting as spokesman for Philip Morris Cos, Inc, R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co, Brown and Williamson Tobacco Corp and Lorillard Tobacco Co.

U.S. District Judge George O'Toole in his ruling earlier Friday upheld a key part of the Massachusetts law finding it was not in conflict with federal legislation that prohibits the secretary of Health and Human Services from disclosing ingredients.
"We obviously disagree with the ruling," Remes said. "Just this Wednesday, another federal court in Alabama held that a state could not disclose the same information that this ruling permits."
Massachusetts Assistant Attorney General Rebecca McIntyre said she expected the tobacco companies' action, saying, "This is wht they do. They exhaust all avenues of appeal.
"We're going to oppose their efforts to have this case appealed...and we're going to continue to go forward to implement the statute," she said.
The Massachusetts law goes into effect on July 1.
